newsitem.title: JAPAN: Ivorian cocoa output forecast unchanged - PM.
newsitem.headline: Ivorian cocoa output forecast unchanged - PM.

text.p: Ivory Coast Prime Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan on Saturday reiterated that the country's cocoa production in the 1996/97 season would be 950,000 tonnes, down from a record 1.2 million tonnes last year.
"We produced more than one million tonnes of cocoa last year. And I still think our production will be 950,000 tonnes this year," the president told reporters in Tokyo.
"Because of our large market share, our overproduction poses the risk of cocoa's global price drops. We'd like to maintain its output at this level," he said.
His comment was made amid recent different forecasts by traders and diplomats about 1996/97 cocoa output in Ivory Coast, the world's largest producer.
UK-based cocoa research group PCR Ltd Managing Director Robert Fish said earlier this week that Ivory Coast's cocoa output in the 1996/97 season is likely to be at least one million tonnes.

A senior Ivorian diplomat this week said in London that bean output in the country will be between 850,000 and 900,000 tonnes. The Ivory Coast president last month revealed his estimate at 950,000 tonnes.

The president also said Ivory Coast will boost exports of processed cocoa products. "We currently process only 20 percent of total cocoa production in Ivory Coast. This ratio should be boosted to 50 percent by the year 2000," he said.

Asked about his price outlook of the world cocoa market, the Ivory Coast's leader said: "I don't have any crystal ball here. But cocoa demand is improving in Asia, for example, and its prices will soon reach a good level."
The West African state's leader is currently visiting Japan to meet with the Japanese government officials and business leaders.
